text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so 
last week I showed you how you can make your

own rice crackers at home now this week I'm going 
to show you a dip that is a classic pairing with

those rice crackers now this dip is a pork shrimp 
coconut peanut dip that's a little spicy it's got

lots of things going on but it's very luscious 
and so delicious and this dish is called Kao

Tung Na Tung so Kao Tung if you saw my other 
video you know that means rice crackers and not

that I don't know how to describe it to yourself 
all my Thai fans if you can help me explain what

Na Tung is in this context please let me know in 
the comments below I could use some help here but

anyway this is super super easy and delicious 
dip let's get started alright I'm gonna start

out by making the Thai mirepoix the garlic white 
peppercorns and cilantro roots so garlic white

peppercorns going in and then cilantro roots I've 
got two here that I've chopped if you want to use

cilantro stems and said um you can't find roots 
that's totally fine as well we call this actually

Sam glue which means three friends and it's a 
three friends that's like the classic base for

a lot of dishes that's it doesn't have to be 
super fine as long as there are no big chunks

you're good to go next I'm gonna add some dried 
chilies for this you can make it a spicier it's

not spicy as you want typically it's not a very 
spicy dish so I'm using the big dried chilies and

I've added just a couple of the smaller spicier 
chilies but this will give a nice color and the

little ones will give a little bit of a kick 
okay but instead of pounding it in here which

takes a long time I always grind my Chili's in 
a coffee grinder separately speeds up things so

much that's it doesn't have to be powdery just 
as long as there are no big flakes you're good

to go oh that looks like a lot maybe this would 
be a little spicier than I had anticipated but

that's okay alright just pound that together 
until they're mixed up and if you don't have

a coffee grinder or one that you're willing to 
grind chilies in you can just quickly soak the

dried chilies in water and then they'll be 
soft and it's easier to pound that way whoa

and careful don't breathe too hard all right it's 
a very simple cooked tip so I just got a pot here

a little bit of vegetable oil so I'm just gonna 
throw the three friends which is now one friend

into the pot here you want to cook off the raw 
garlic and infuse all that flavor into the oil

so once it's sort of starting to brown and some of 
it will start to thick just go in with the coconut

milk and this set of coconut milk I'm actually 
going to reduce until thick because I want the

dip to be really luscious and creamy reduce it 
down and concentrate all that good coconut flavor

so while that's reducing I'm going to show you 
my proteins have got here half half ground pork

and ground shrimp and the ground trim I just buy 
shrimp and just chopped up chop them up with a

cleaver super super easy now I know you're gonna 
ask can you use chicken instead can I just do pork

and adjust the tree yes yes and yes you can this 
is just what's classic you can change it up and

do shrimp only pork only chicken only the only 
thing I won't do is because beef has a really

strong flavor all right so now it's thicken the 
oil from the coconut milk it's actually starting

to separate out I'm gonna go in with the protein 
and I'm gonna just work really hard to not have

big lumps because remember this is a dip so you 
don't want big chunks in your dip right you want

it to be quite fine spatulas way too flexible and 
changing weapon there we go so I can break up any

lumps if I need to okay so once there are no big 
chunks anymore I'm gonna add the other half of

my coconut milk and also all the seasonings so 
I've got here some fish sauce very classic Thai

seasoning actually some tamron's I've got salty 
now the sour so you want this to have a little

bit of a tartness but not too tart and also some 
sugar palm sugar of course and just stir that in

and peanuts now this is roasted ground peanuts 
that I roasted fresh and I ground it up so it's

still a little gritty so no peanut butter here 
hey you want that texture so I ground this up in

a food processor I'm gonna let this simmer for 
about three more minutes what I want is for the

peanuts to absorb all that liquid for the flavors 
really mingle and marry so it comes together in

one cohesive dish and also it's gonna thicken 
up a little bit if it becomes too thick you

can always add a splash of water so no big deal 
there all right that looks really good so this

is sort of the consistency you're going for now 
I'm gonna throw in some thinly sliced shallots

and let that cook down for just about 30 seconds 
to a minute just to take off that raw flavor oh

that's thickened up on me quite a bit so I'm gonna 
just add in a little more water just a little at a

time a little water goes a long way in this tip I 
always surprise myself how much it spins out just

with a little splash and there you go that's 
perfect I'm gonna turn this off all right so

I'm gonna give it a taste because when you're 
dealing with things that simmer and reduce you

just never know how concentrated it has become 
and also just Tamron in here and that's always

something you want to taste because different 
brands vary quite a bit mmm mmm mmm spot-on

and you definitely want to serve this dip warm 
this to me just smells so Thai and if you get a

little bit of oil separation don't worry about it 
okay that's totally normal happens sometimes it's

kind of pretty too all right I'm going to serve 
this with some rice crackers of course that we

made last week and garnish very very simple you 
can just put a dry chilli it's always pretty

and a little cilantro right on top and there 
you go that's a classic Thai appetizer right

there super pretty super delicious let me dig in 
a little bit on the rice cracker a little bit more

it's a very flavorful tip sweet salty sour in 
perfect balance and rich and creamy coconut

this kind of brings everything together so 
I hope you give this a try it's super super

easy and what's great about this tip is that 
you can make it in advance so if you have a

party it's one less thing to worry about just 
reheat it and serve so the recipe is away so

beyond hot Thai Kitchen calm when you make it 
send me photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram

oh and I'm also now on snapchat and if you 
haven't subscribed to the show please do so

right here so you never miss an episode and I 
will see you next time for your next delicious
